articles.title: OCTOBER 1989
articles.summary: This document outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) scheduled events for October and early November 1989. Key activities include public star parties, general meetings featuring speakers like John Gleason on astrophotography and Dr. Jeff Cuzzi on Voyager discoveries, and an introductory observational astronomy class. The schedule also highlights an AAAC Astronomical Conference in November.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The article 'Field of View' presents two main topics: 'Night Fishing with Picasso' details John Gleason's impressive photographic results using a Celestron 8-inch Schmidt camera, building on the historical significance of Schmidt cameras in astronomy research. It also includes a 'Public Star Parties - Reminder!!!' announcing a series of free public observing sessions hosted by SJAA at Branham Lane Park in San Jose on select Friday evenings in October, November, and December, aimed at public education.

articles.title: Volunteers are needed!
articles.summary: The article is a call for volunteers to bring their telescopes and share their knowledge of the night sky with the public. It reassures potential volunteers that even limited expertise is valuable to those new to astronomy, highlighting the rewarding experience of introducing beginners to celestial objects and the flexibility of team-based scheduling for ongoing events.

articles.title: T57'S CENTRAL STAR VIEWED FROM LOS GATOS RED CROSS!!!
articles.summary: The article reports on an Autumn swap meet where attendees enjoyed telescope-making accessories and observing supplies. The event featured impressive slide shows, including lunar eclipse photos and Schmidt camera images, alongside promising work from beginner astrophotographers. A highlight was the demonstration of a new CCD camera which, when attached to an 8-inch telescope, allowed participants to view the 14.5 magnitude central star of the Ring Nebula from the Los Gatos Red Cross parking lot.

articles.title: DARKNESS SQUANDERING TIME
articles.summary: An upcoming Star Party on November 26 will coincide with the end of Daylight Saving Time, requiring participants to set their watches back an hour at 2:00 am. Attendees are also prompted to consider re-observing previously viewed celestial objects during the event.

articles.title: ASTRONOMY AND TELESCOPE MAKING RENEWALS
articles.summary: This document announces the renewal period for Astronomy and Telescope Making magazines, detailing subscription costs ($14.50 and $8.50 respectively), payment instructions via Jim Van Nuland, and a strict November 1st deadline for group renewals. It also promotes the 1989 AANC Astronomical Conference to be held November 18-19 at the Lawrence Hall of Science, featuring speakers like Dr. David Morrison, Jerry Sherlin, and George Keene, who will cover topics such as Neptune results, amateur solar astronomy, and astrophotography techniques.

articles.title: Astrophotography contest and exhibit (get your best shots ready), cosmic art exhibition, DOOR PRIZES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
articles.summary: The article announces an upcoming conference featuring an astrophotography contest and exhibit, a cosmic art exhibition, and door prizes. It provides details for paper submissions, contact information for the astrophotography contest, and registration fees and deadlines for the two-day event.

articles.title: COMET OKAZAKI-LEVY-RUDENKO
articles.summary: Comet Okazaki-Levy-Rudenko (1989r) was discovered in late August by Kiyomi Okazaki, David Levy, and Michael Rudenko. Currently a 10th-magnitude object in Bootes, it is projected to brighten to 4th magnitude later in the fall after rounding the Sun in November and becoming a morning object.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: ASTRO ADS is a free classifieds section provided for non-commercial advertisers to sell astronomically related products and services. The listings feature a diverse range of used telescopes, including Newtonians, Schmidt-Cassegrains, and refractors, along with various accessories such as mounts, drive correctors, eyepieces, and specialized filters. Each advertisement includes product descriptions, pricing, and contact information for potential buyers.

articles.title: TUTHILL Polar Axis finder/with instructions. $85. Bill Dillinges 415-792-9206
articles.summary: This document is a classifieds listing advertising several pieces of astronomical equipment for sale. Items include a TUTHILL Polar Axis finder, a KOLKACH Roll Film Cold Camera, and various telescopes and mounts from brands like Celestron, Edmund, and Bausch & Lomb. Each listing provides a price, condition details, and contact information for potential buyers.

articles.title: VOYAGER'S DISCOVERIES AT NEPTUNE MOUNT
articles.summary: On August 24, Voyager II performed a close flyby of Neptune, capturing high-resolution photos and returning significant data. The probe revealed Neptune's 16-hour rotation rate, a -354Â°F surface temperature, a magnetic field tilted 50 degrees, and atmospheric features like 700 mph winds and a Great Dark Spot. Furthermore, Voyager II confirmed at least six rings and detailed characteristics of its moon Triton, including its size and nitrogen-methane atmosphere.

articles.title: GALILEO LAUNCH SCHEDULED FOR OCTOBER 12TH
articles.summary: The Galileo Jupiter orbiter probe is scheduled for launch aboard the space shuttle Atlantis on October 12th. Atlantis will deploy Galileo into low Earth orbit, after which an IUS booster will propel it towards Venus for a gravity assist. The spacecraft will then use another Earth gravity assist before finally heading to Jupiter, with an expected arrival in 1995.

articles.title: DELTA MAKES FIRST U.S. COMMERCIAL LAUNCH
articles.summary: McDonnell Douglas successfully conducted the first commercial satellite launch by a private U.S. company on August 27th. A Delta booster was used to orbit the Marcopolo I direct broadcast relay satellite for British Satellite Broadcasting Ltd.

articles.title: HIPPARCOS ASTRONOMY SATELLITE FAILS TO REACH ORBIT
articles.summary: The HIPPARCOS astronomy satellite, designed by the European Space Agency for precise stellar positional measurements, failed to reach its intended geostationary orbit. Although launched by an Ariane booster, its apogee motor repeatedly failed to ignite. Consequently, the satellite is now in a lower transfer orbit, where its operational lifespan is reduced to an estimated 12-18 months instead of the planned 2.5 years.

articles.title: COSMONAUTS REOCCUPY MIR
articles.summary: A two-man crew successfully reoccupied the Soviet MIR space station on September 5th, manually docking after an automatic system failure. The mission aims to expand MIR with two large modules over the next 4-5 months. The first module, expected in October, will provide additional gyros, oxygen supply, a shower, and a manned maneuvering unit, while the second, due in January/February, will feature a docking port for the Soviet space shuttle.

articles.title: SOVIET PLANETARY PLANS HAVE CHANGED
articles.summary: The Soviet Union has announced a simplification of its 1994 Mars mission plans. The revised strategy involves sending two spacecraft, each equipped with an orbiter and a balloon designed to explore the Martian surface.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz reports on the recent discovery of a new bright comet, Okazaki-Levy-Rudenko (1989r), which was independently found by three observers in late August and is expected to become naked-eye visible in November, offering an uninterrupted view from the Northern Hemisphere. The article also briefly notes the dimming of Periodic Comet Brorsen-Metcalf and an update regarding dropped plans for a manned Mars mission in 2015.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Brorsen-Metcalf (1989o)
articles.summary: This article provides observational data (ephemeris and magnitude) for Periodic Comet Brorsen-Metcalf (1989o) and Comet Okazaki-Levy-Rudenko (1989r) for late 1989. It then delves into the phenomenon of comets experiencing rapid brightness outbursts before discovery, discussing its implications for systematic comet hunting and presenting six historical examples. The article concludes by analyzing differences in brightening rates for comets discovered in the morning versus evening sky, suggesting morning sky comets show greater variance.

articles.title: MORNING DISCOVERIES
articles.summary: This document page, titled "MORNING DISCOVERIES," presents two identical graphical representations of magnitude change over a 10-day period. The graphs display numerous data points, indicating changes in brightness ranging from significantly brighter to somewhat dimmer, suggesting a record of new astronomical observations.

articles.title: EVENING DISCOVERIES
articles.summary: The article explains how the apparent brightness of comets is affected by their proximity to both Earth and the Sun. Comets in the morning sky often brighten rapidly as they approach, while those in the evening sky generally recede from Earth, leading to dimming or moderate brightening depending on their solar distance.

articles.title: GREAT RED SPOT BY: JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: Jim Van Nuland reports on the start of Jupiter season at Calico Observatory, successfully recovering the Great Red Spot (GRS) on August 13. He notes significant changes on Jupiter, including the apparent disappearance of the South Equatorial Belt (SEB) and the GRS appearing a pale orange, though its longitude remains consistent with predictions. The article also provides historical context for the GRS and offers practical tips for amateur astronomers observing Jupiter and tracking the Spot.

articles.title: Great Red Spot on Meridian PDT
articles.summary: This document provides a detailed schedule of times when Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) will be on the meridian, observed from a location using Pacific Daylight Time (PDT). The table lists specific dates and times throughout October and November, offering guidance for observers interested in viewing this prominent feature.

articles.title: BY: PATRICK M. DONNELLY
articles.summary: This article provides a detailed observing guide to the constellation Delphinus, focusing on numerous double and multiple star systems. The author, Patrick M. Donnelly, shares personal observations, magnitudes, separations, and perceived colors for stars like Gamma, Alpha, Beta, and Kappa Delphini, as well as several Sigma and Beta designations. It also mentions a planetary nebula (NGC 6905) and discusses challenges and discoveries during deep-sky observing.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings at the Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California, featuring guest speakers on diverse astronomical topics and informal "Indoor Star Parties." These gatherings foster a friendly atmosphere for enthusiasts interested in astrophotography, deep-sky observation, telescope making, or armchair observing. Meetings occur on the first Saturday of each month, with doors opening at 7:45 PM for an 8 PM start, and detailed directions are provided.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The article describes "Indoor Star Parties" as informal Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomers to connect, discuss astronomy, and enjoy camaraderie. Attendees are encouraged to bring telescopes and accessories to share, with activities ranging from outdoor observing and astrophotography slideshows to SJAA Board meetings and introductory astronomy workshops. These events foster community and learning among astronomy enthusiasts.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary:
## FIELD EXPEDITIONS

On the Saturdays closest to the New Moon, the SJAA will conduct a "Star Party" for astronomical observation at a designated location. Several times a year these star parties are ...

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is a highly popular observing location for Bay Area amateur astronomers, situated 70 miles south of San Jose. Rising nearly 3000 ft., it serves as a gathering spot for serious deep-sky observing and astrophotography during New Moon weekends, often hosting 50-100 telescopes in summer. The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) frequently sets up in Coulter Camp and publishes the monthly 'EPHEMERIS', with contact information for its officers and board members.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), detailing different membership types (Membership Only, Membership/S&T, Junior Under 18) and their respective costs. It provides instructions for submission, including payment details to the treasurer, Jack Peterson, and contact information for the association.
